content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see two large, ovoid tissue fragments, consistent with lymph nodes, embedded in adipose tissue. Both of these potential lymph nodes are almost entirely replaced by a dense, basophilic (dark purple) infiltrate, which is highly suspicious for massive metastatic carcinoma. Several smaller tissue fragments are also present. My initial impression is that these are at least two positive lymph nodes.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

The low-power view strongly suggests metastatic disease in the two large lymph nodes. I am zooming into the superior-most of these two suspicious lymph nodes to confirm this impression. The purpose is to examine the cytological and architectural features of the infiltrating cells at high magnification to confirm they are malignant and consistent with adenocarcinoma from a colorectal primary. I also want to assess the extent of involvement and look for features like extranodal extension at the periphery of the node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the periphery of the tumor deposit in the second lymph node (the one on the right). This specific location is crucial for several reasons: 1) to confirm the malignant nature of the infiltrating cells at high power, 2) to assess the interface between the tumor and the surrounding tissue, and most importantly, 3) to evaluate for extranodal extension (ENE), which is the invasion of tumor cells through the lymph node capsule into the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue. The selected area is at the edge of the node, adjacent to fat, making it the ideal location to look for ENE. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the periphery of the lower lymph node. This is a crucial area for assessing the lymph node capsule and the interface with the surrounding perinodal fat. The main reason is to look for evidence of extranodal extension (ENE), where the tumor breaks through the capsule and invades the adjacent soft tissue. The presence or absence of ENE is a critical prognostic factor and affects staging. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, the lymph node architecture is almost completely effaced and replaced by a malignant infiltrate. The tumor consists of crowded, back-to-back glands with cribriform and solid patterns. The neoplastic cells have large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei. This morphology is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is a positive lymph node with extensive metastatic involvement. The dark, linear streaks are artifacts, likely due to tissue folding.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see a dense, monotonous sheet of malignant cells with dark, irregular nuclei and scant cytoplasm, consistent with metastatic carcinoma. At the top of the image, these tumor cells are clearly infiltrating into the mature adipose tissue without an intervening lymph node capsule. This finding is diagnostic of extranodal extension (ENE). My impression is a positive lymph node with metastatic carcinoma showing definite extranodal extension.
This is ROI 3. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I can see the edge of the densely cellular lymph node on the right. The dark, basophilic cells, which are suspicious for metastatic carcinoma, are seen infiltrating directly into the surrounding adipose tissue (the large, clear, circular spaces are fat cells). There is no clear, intact fibrous capsule separating the nodal tissue from the fat. This observation is highly indicative of extranodal extension (ENE). On the far left, a blood vessel is visible within the perinodal fat.
